Journal Story:
Jody, Levi and I have concluded that this is our year to hike the AT.Â  Everything is lining up and I am not getting any younger, so would like to take advantage of this open window while it is available.Â  We intend (hope) to thru hike the entire trail from Georgia to Maine.Â  It is 2193 miles, so will take us 5+ months.Â  My wonderful, beautiful wife has been beyond supportive of my bucket list idea, so, MANY MANY thank yous to the greatest, most amazing wife in the history of the universe.Â  I am so grateful for this opportunity.Â  I would never be able to repay her for this.Â Â 
Â We will be doing what is referred to as a 'flip-flop' hike.Â  Our plan is for Levi and I to take our camper to southern Vermont and park it with my niece (thank you Tim and Beth).Â  Then we will rent a car one way and drive to Port Clinton PA and start our hike, walking north on April 20.Â  Â  On May 26 Jody and Gavan will fly to Vermont and meet up with us when we get there (hopefully about the same time).Â  From there Jody and Gavan will meet up with us via the camper every couple/few daysÂ  as we head north.Â  When we get to Mt. Katahdin, Maine, we will drive back to Port Clinton PA and start south.Â  Around the third week of July, Jody will need to head back home for school.Â  We will continue to walk south from there until we get to Springer Mountain, Georgia.
* A bad day outside is better than a good day inside

This past Monday I went over my plan with my manager at work and she was very supportive of everything (thank you Genevieve).Â  As a contractor there are no assurances of available work in the future, but I was glad for the positive conversation.Â  My friends at work and church are interested in following the adventure, so that has been fun sharing the details.Â  One friend from work is planning to join us for some time when we walk through the Great Smoky National Park.Â  That will definitely be fun.Â  As of today we are 14 days away from heading out.Â  I think I am ready.Â  Yesterday Elijah came home from college for 4 days so we can spend some good time together.Â  I won't get to see Elijah hardly at all during the summer, so that is the one negative thing for sure.Â  I am taking a ball cap that he gave me from his school (LeTourneau University) so I will keep him close that way.Â  He plans on making a trip or two out to see us while we are hiking, so that will be good.Â  Â 
*Â  The decisions you make today, tomorrow will make you

Today started out a little rough with Levi heading to the airport to go home. It is not how either of us envisioned the second week ending, but here we are. Todays hiking had a little of everything. So once again last night I seem to have found a stealth camping spot withÂ Â no cell coverage. Whenever I do not make a blog update that is usually the reason why.Â 
So in the morning I make the 2.7 mile walk back to the trail (which do not count towards the daily or cumulative miles because they are not on the trail) and begin to hike on. So the path was relatively easy today which was good because I had a long walk just to get to the trail. It always amazes me how much the trail can change from mile to mile. Today was another relatively easy day. There were not a lot of steep ups and downs, and the temperatures were pleasant. Shortly after lunch I came to a place where someone left trail magic. So last night I had an interesting encounter. Â When I got to the shelter there was a man, my age, there who was section hiking the opposite direction. We had a great conversation for a couple of hours. Â What was interesting was that he worked as the chief editor for the foreign news bureau Â at the Washington Post. Today was a good day because I got to look forward to ending it in a hotel, complete with a shower, air conditioning and a soft bed. Â Today I also discovered the notorious Vermont black flies.
